events.name: First Meetup, 24.04.2014
events.description:
We're very happy to announce our first meetup which will be held 24.04. at STYLIGHT HQ (http://www.stylight.de).  

There will be food, beer and plenty of time for networking.

Talks:

- Writing a Web Crawler - Lessons learned by Dmitry Savintsev (Yahoo)

- Crunching data with go: tips, tricks, use-cases by Sergii Khomenko (Stylight)

Schedule:

- Food / Beer / Networking (ugh)

- Few words by our sponsors

- First talk (20-45min)

- Short Break

- Second talk (20-45min)

Want to contribute ? Have some ideas? We're always looking for speakers, hosts / locations and sponsors.

Stay tuned for updates.

events.name: Meetup in September
events.description:
The next meetup is scheduled for 11. September 2014.  Proposals for talks are very welcome :).

Talks:

1) Lessons learned when making 'godi' by Sebastian Thiel

Sebastian is a software engineer rooted in the VFX industry. Having worked on technical challenges in movies like "Iron Man 3" and "Captain America: The Winter Solder", he took care of automating IT systems and offloading expensive tasks to the compute farm. 'Written languages' are python, c++ and by now, go.

Learning a new programming language is best achieved by solving an actual problem. godi is the project I used to learn go and I will share the most exciting things about go that were revealed to me in the process. The speech will be held from the perspective of a go-beginner, showing aspects of the go language using actual code of godi

2) TBA

Location

STYLIGHT

events.name: Meetup in November
events.description:
Talks:

1. Writing web applications in go - frameworks and libraries - Dominic Phillips (STYLIGHT)

2. dotGo conference report - Dmitry Savintsev (Yahoo)

Dmitry will share his impressions of the recent dotGo conference (http://www.dotgo.eu/) and what he learned from the talks, workshop and bar conversations.

3. A simple Go build tool - Claus Strasburger (mgm technology partners / Student @ TUM)

events.name: First meetup of 2015: webseclab web security tests and Rust vs Go comparison
events.description:
We are happy to announce the first meetup of 2015!

Talks:

Webseclab - security scanning test suite in Go - Dmitry Savintsev, Yahoo!

Webseclab - security scanning test suite in Go.

"Webseclab"  - is a set of tests for the scanner and framework to do experiments and proof of concepts/demos. It is similar in spirit to the recently released "firing range", webgoat or DVWA ("Damn Vulnerable Web Application") but thanks to the Go implementation may have special or even unique features.It is extremely easy to fire up (no dependencies and no Tomcat setup or such needed) which allows you to turn any random VM or host into a functional web security "lab". Also, switching between Go's text and html templates, we get "for free" - with just a few lines of extra code - a set of "fixed" tests where the injections are neutralized by proper output escaping which comes especially useful for training and communicating with developers. The webseclab is optimized for rapid addition of new tests and cases - we have been using it to "resurrect" already fixed issues reported through the BugBounty program and quickly convert HTTP dumps into realistic tests ready to be used for scanner improvement.

Webseclab is the first Go project released by Yahoo at Github: https://github.com/yahoo/webseclab

Related FOSDEM talk description:

https://fosdem.org/2015/schedule/event/go_web_security_scanner/

Ru-Go-La - It's not a salad! - Sebastian Thiel

 Rust is the up-and-coming systems programming language that promises safety without sacrificing performance. Go on the other hand already established itself as language for building

The first part shall be a short Rust whereas the second one will show Rust's main language features using actual programs and compares them to the respective go implementation. 

Topics we touch will be: 

• The Borrow-Checker

• Polymorphism

• Concurrency Patterns

• C-Interop 

• Standard Library and Libraries

• Performance and Efficiency

• Testing and Benchmarking

• Dependencies and Deployment

events.name: Second meetup of 2015:
events.description:
Time flies fast and it's again time to have a meet-up. This time we have a famous engineer and speaker - Brad Fitzpatrick.

Talks:

The state of the Gopher - Brad Fitzpatrick from the Go Team at Google talks about summary of past Go releases and what's currently in progress for the upcoming Go 1.5 release.

We are still open for the second speaker... Write me a message if you want to present a lighting talk or long one

events.name: Third meetup of 2015: Channel Pipeline processing with Go @ DigitalOcean
events.description:
DigitalOcean is visiting us as a part of their Worldwide Golanging tour.

Talks:

Go's generate tool to help write channel pipeline processing code - Ian Hansen, DigitalOcean

Pipeline patterns from cancelation to channels of channels. How to use the go generate tool. Then, making a tool to generate pipelines.

We are open for your proposals... Write me a message if you want to present a lighting talk or long one

events.name: Meetup Jun 16th - Google Munich
events.description:
When? Jun 16th, 7pm

Where? Google Munich, Dienerstraße 12, 80331 

Talks? 

Sneak preview of "Go Dynamic Tools" - Dmitry Vyukov, Staff Software Engineer at Google

Dynamic tools can provide significant value for small time investment. But frequently they are underappreciated by developers. In this talk I will describe three dynamic tools for Go: data race detector, fuzzing system and execution tracer. The first two tools are related to bug finding, and the tracer can give insights into performance and latency issues of Go programs. I will also share our experiences of systematically applying such tools at scale.

As always, don't hesitate to send in your proposals.

* Space is very limited, please cancel you RSVP if you're unable to make it.

events.name: 1. October Meetup
events.description:
Talks:

GO & PHP by Jan Halfar

Go and PHP are very different in almost every aspect:

• Compiled vs interpreted

• Statically typed vs dynamically typed

• Concurrency vs process isolation

• Long living processes vs per request lifetime

The opposing approach to almost everything is what makes Go and PHP complement one another so well.

Adding Go to our PHP stack helped us to overcome some of our **favourite** problems when building large websites with PHP. In this talk, we want to show, how we used Go in combination with **TYPO3 Neos** to build a large website with (almost) no caching.

Jan Halfar, 44 years old family man, co-founder of bestbytes a software workshop. Studied architecture and got drawn into software development in the late nineties, still stuck there - I guess I like it.


Turtle - Rock Solid Cluster Management by Roland Singer

Turtle is a cluster management tool written in Go which makes use of
open source technologies as Docker, Rocket, BTRFS, OverlayFS, Ceph, KVM,
....
It's a complete new way to handle your servers. It's designed after the KISS principal and focuses on user-friendliness and security. TURTLE takes care about container setups, virtualizations, load-balancing, backups, distribution and monitoring. This system is used in production at DesertBit.

BitMonster framework and Glue socket library by Roland Singer

BitMonster is a powerful platform for real-time mobile or web applications. It uses a new straightforward approach to connect frontends with a real-time backend. This technology is base on an open source real-time bidirectional socket library called Glue. It is a clean, robust and efficient alternative to socket.io. This library is designed to connect webbrowsers with a go-backend in a simple way. It automatically detects supported socket layers and chooses the most suitable one. This library handles automatic reconnections on disconnections and handles caching to bridge those disconnections. The server implementation is thread-safe.

Roland Singer, 21 years old, founder of Manjaro Linux and DesertBit. Focusing on IT-Security, Linux systems, web environments and server solutions. I'm having a great experience with the Go programming language and I really enjoy working with it! Dumped C++ for it...

events.name: First in 2016, 28th January

venue.name: hybris GmbH
venue.address_1: Nymphenburger Str. 82, München.  Directly by Maillingerstrasse UBahn  (U1/U7)

events.description:
A huge thank you to Hybris for hosting us this time!

Food & Swag sponsored by Stripe - https://stripe.com/jobs#engineering.

Talks:

Ben Bieker on Go Generate

- What is go generate?

- Code generation? Why would you do that?

- What can you do with go generate?

- Yacc, features, how to use it, origins. 

- Practical examples / patterns.

events.name: Second meetup of 2016
events.description:
Talks:

GopherJS - A Go to JavaScript compiler - Peter Paolucci 

GopherJS compiles Go code to pure JavaScript code. This allows writing front-end code in Go, which then runs in the browser. We will have a look at the tools and their usage by providing a few examples. We will focus on the generated code and compare the performance of native Go and Go translated to JS by using the compute-intensive n-body problem as a basis. We will also have a look at various ways how our Go code can access the DOM to create animated SVGs in browsers.

Hey fellow gophers,

We are planning to organise another meetup. Ping us if you have something cool to share or if you have some nice golang packages and you are interested to have a lighting talk about it.

Cheers,

Dom & Sergii

events.name: October meetup of 2016
events.description:
After a long summer break, we are again ready to get together and enjoy the awesome talks!

Talks:

Implementing cross-platform 'tail -f' - Fabian Stäber ( https://github.com/fstab ), ConSol

As part of a log file monitoring tool, I implemented a file tailer that keeps reading new lines from log files. This turned out to be much more challenging than I thought, especially because it should run on multiple operating systems and it should be robust against logrotate. In this 15-20 Minutes talk I will present the lessons learned, the pitfalls and dead-ends I ran into.

The monitoring tool is https://github.com/fstab/grok_exporter

Fabian is software developer, R&D lead, and consultant at ConSol Software GmbH in Munich.

Glide and Go Dependency Management - Dmitry Savintsev, Yahoo!

Go package dependencies are traditionally regarded as a thorny problem but the Go vendoring mechanism (from go1.5) and third party tools provide ways to manage it. This talk will share our nearly year-long experience of using Glide ( http://glide.sh) to manage third-party and internal dependencies as part of an automated continuous integration build system, and the best practices we came up with for our teams and developers.

Profiling Go Applications in Production - Dmitri Melikyan

Production environments are different from development and staging. Whether optimizing application performance or trying to find a problem root cause, it is often necessary to use Go's profiling tools in production environment. In this talk I'll share my experience of profiling/monitoring production apps and demo the related tool I've been working on.

Dmitri is a software engineer, who is building profiling and monitoring products for the last few years.

Golang at Sixt and where we are going with it - Boyan Dimitrov   

In this talk we are going to share our experience of using Golang at Sixt as an integral part of our cloud stack underpinning our latest products. We are going to talk about the path of adoption and how we build and run our applications.

Boyan is the Director of Platform Engineering at Sixt where he is working on a global scale microservices mobility ecosystem. Prior to that he was the Platform Automation Lead at Hailo where he worked on the transition from a monolith system to a microservices architecture with over 250 services based on Golang. Boyan is specialising in distributed systems, highly-scalable applications and cloud automation.

Looking forward to meeting you!

Sergii & Dom

events.name: Second meetup of 2017: Open Source and Key validation

venue.name: hybris GmbH
venue.address_1: Nymphenburger Str. 82, München.  Directly by Maillingerstrasse UBahn  (U1/U7)

events.description:
Agenda:

Sign me up - OpenPGP Email Key validation with Go - Johannes Ebke, TNG Technology Consulting

Encrypted email has been around for over 20 years. At TNG Technology Consulting, we use OpenPGP-encrypted mail extensively for confidential conversations. However, its usability for the general public is still not great - problems include long setup procedures, lost passphrases, and the difficulty of finding out if your communications partners can actually decrypt what you sent them. Using a Key Validation Server written in Go, we attempt to overcome the last problem with the help of automation: With this server you can test if your OpenPGP setup works as intended, and your key gains a machine-readable signature certifying this. Other clients can then use this as a hint to automatically encrypt email going to you. In addition to presenting the validation handshake, we will have a look into the details of handling emails with Go, have fun with MIME and hack x/crypto/openpgp.

Johannes Ebke is Senior Consultant at TNG Technology Consulting. Formerly analyzing data on the grid as a particle physicist at CERN, he's now working on cloud-based distributed web systems. Most of his work with Go is in writing, fixing and extending DevOps tools for CI, CD and monitoring.

Pragmatic Learnings from Writing Open-Source Projects -  Anthony Najjar Simon

https://github.com/anthonynsimon/bild - 1444 stars on GitHub.

Writing good Open-Source Software can be a big challenge. Fortunately, it's also an immensely fulfilling experience as you get to work with some really smart people and it's also a great opportunity to learn something new while building a portfolio of cool projects. 

We'll talk about various do's and don'ts learned after writing two popular Go projects, "Bild" (~1.450k stars) and "Parrot" (~800 stars), and the challenges that came with them. These tips might prove useful not only if you're thinking of starting your own projects, but also if you'd like to collaborate to existing ones.

Anthony Najjar Simon is a Software Developer from sunny Costa Rica

events.name: Third of 2017: Higher-Order Functions in Go / general-purpose work queue
events.description:
We are ready to kick with a new cool event on June 1st. 

Please send us your proposals. We still open for speakers: one can bring a lighting talk on a small hack or bring a full-blown talk on anything related to Golang!

Agenda:

Higher-Order Functions in Go - Stefan Hans

The talk shows some pattern of functional programming in Go from a beginners point of view. Actually, the talk is rather influenced by Scala. But a more Go oriented "Functional Streaming" part is planned.

Stefan Hans was working never officially as a developer but developing ever since he started working IT in the late-Nineties. After the announcement of the outsourcing of his workplace to an IT service company, he reoriented himself and caught up on cutting-edge technologies like cloud, big data, and IoT. Checking out a modern general-purpose language he put his main focus from Scala to Go and was writing his first Go code last February being an enthusiastic Go fan ever since.

Beanstalkg - Yet another fast, general-purpose work queue - Vimukthi Wickramasinghe

The talk is a personal open source project in Go, Beanstalkg. The goal of the project is to rewrite Beanstalkd, a very popular open source work queue while also supporting high availability and failover built in. 

Vimukthis experience primarily is in the financial industry working as Java backend developer. But he has been writing Go code on and off for various personal projects since 2012. He never contributed any open source code in Go until last year when he developed a client library for his employer. He loves writing Go and guarantees that there's more to come.

More information TBA. Stay tuned! 

https://twitter.com/munich_gophers

Cheers,

Sergii

events.name: Fourth of 2017: Friendly DNS with Golang
events.description:
Talks:

Friendly DNS with Golang - Dan Lüdtke, eGym

How we used Golang to make DNS zone data management less human unfriendly and automated deployments to Google CloudDNS.

Dan Lüdtke is a Site Reliability Engineer at eGym GmbH. He served his country, worked as a cyber security consultant in Europe and the U.S., wrote a book about Internet protocols, contributes to popular open source projects, regularly helps to organize Europes largest hacker conference, enjoys cycling and dreams of space travel.

SPEAKERS

We are always looking for stories of your experiences! Submit a full-blown talk of 40min or just a short lightning talk of 10 min.

Friendly events

Friends of us are organizing one of the cool events in Paris -https://www.dotgo.eu/ and they are happy to share a discount - GOMUNICH

Or just a direct link: https://dotgo2017.eventbrite.com?discount=GOMUNICH

They are also happy to add our logo to the website, but we need a designer for this. Is any of you a designer? Would be super helpful!

events.name: K8s API & Go Programming - Joint meetup with München Kubernetes/Cloud-Native

venue.name: hybris GmbH
venue.address_1: Nymphenburger Str. 82, München.  Directly by Maillingerstrasse UBahn  (U1/U7)

events.description:
A joint meeting with
https://www.meetup.com/Munchen-Kubernetes-Meetup/events/246708125/

i hope everyone had refreshing holidays and is ready for our next meetup, it's just around the corner. Antoine from SAP is going to talk about the extensibility of the Kubernetes API and Stefan is going to give an intro into how to start go programming for and with Kubernetes.

6:30 pm : Doors open
7:00 pm : Talks
Talk #1 : Antoine Cotten: Extensibility of the Kubernetes API
Talk #2 : Stefan Hans: Go for and with Kubernetes

8:30 pm : Networking, Drinks & Snacks

**************************************************

Talk #1
Are you interested in learning more about the extensibility of the Kubernetes API? Let's take a look together at a new Lambda-like prototype put together by Google, and presented at KubeCon in December.
After a short recap about the general design of a Kubernetes controller (or "operator"), I will explore how a developer can build the same kind of automation by providing a simple language-agnostic function.
Feel free to jump in already by taking a look at the project on GitHub: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kube-metacontroller

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Talk #2
How to start to do Go programming for and with Kubernetes? Current experiences and lessons learned from using kubernetes/client-go trying to help you start

About Stefan
Stefan has almost never officially worked as a programmer, but has always programmed since he started working in IT in the late-Nineties.
After the announcement of the outsourcing of his workplace to an IT service company, he reoriented himself and caught up on cutting-edge technologies like Cloud, Big Data, IoT, AI etc.
Checking out a modern general-purpose language he put his main focus from Scala to Go. He wrote his first Go code last February and has been an enthusiastic Go fan ever since. Currently, he is on the way to deep dive into Kubernetes and is starting to do Go programming for the cloud ecosystem in cooperation with Loodse GmbH.

events.name: Munich Hack Day at Stylight
events.description:
• What we'll do
Munich Hack Days are all about getting us working on our hobby projects and pushing them forward. We do not have a specific focus or topic this time. Just come and join fellow geeks to have a day of hobby project fun!

This is a joint event together with the Munich iOS Developers meetup (https://www.meetup.com/The-Munich-iOS-Developers-Meetup/) and GDG Munich Android (https://www.meetup.com/GDG-Munich-Android/)! Come take advantage of the opportunity to meet people working in different tech and learn from each other.

If you don't have your own project yet maybe now is the perfect time to start one? Or maybe you can find a project looking for help you can join?

Please note that places are VERY limited. Do register only if you can make it. If something unexpected comes up please cancel your RSVP.

RSVP ONLY TO ONE OF THE GROUPS!

• What to bring
Whatever you need to hack on your hobby projects.

• Important to know

events.name: Building robots using Go; Going deep with Go crawling

venue.name: hybris GmbH
venue.address_1: Nymphenburger Str. 82, München.  Directly by Maillingerstrasse UBahn  (U1/U7)

events.description:
We are coming back! With cool speakers! Stay tuned!

SLOT1: Building robots using Go - Johannes Engelke

The Programming language GO is a pretty good fit for IoT-Applications. Go-Applications haveing a small foot print and can be compiled for different Processor Architectures and Operating Systems. Beside that offers Go an efficient concurrency model. This allows a simple integration with sensors and aktors.

As part of this talk I will show, how to solve IoT-Problems with go and the Gobot framework.

SLOT2: In to deep - how to use go to crawl the WWW - Korbinian Döpper and Robert Schmalholz

Go's concurrency patterns assist a developer in processing multiple tasks at a time. By building a tiny web crawler, we will provide some insights in how to use go's concurrency patterns. Furthermore, we will present common pitfalls when working with goroutines and channels.

We are looking for speakers and sponsors!

As always, we are super happy to have you with a lightning talk on your small or big successes, open source projects or just something amazing you would like to share.

events.name: Munich Gophers are back!
events.description:
We are back with an awesome host and nice location!

SLOT1: Go for Data Science with Gonum - Bettina Schieche
The talk intends to show how to possibly implement a neural network in Go to classify handwritten digits. It especially makes use of the following concepts:
- Gonum for matrix operations and optimization
- Concurrent hyperparameter tuning with goroutines and channels.
- Web server to interactively modify model parameters

SLOT2: Client side load balancing - Boban Acimovic
Short abstract:
* we will use Solr cluster and Zookeeper as example
* request-response pattern
* goroutines and channels
* possibility to use circuit-breaker pattern

SLOT3: Flying drones with Go - Boban Acimovic
Demo flight and a bit of code

We need your input as speakers! Please approach me if you are interested to present either a normal talk of 40 min or more like lightning talk of 10-20 min

Cheers,
Sergii

events.name: October Gophers: Drivers in Go; GCP apps; go1.11 modules
events.description:
Next event of Munich Gophers!

SLOT1: Writing a driver for a digital signal synthesizer array - Bodo Kaiser

Nowadays, hardware libraries like gobot.io and periph.io make it very simple to use low-level interfaces in Go. In this talk I want to share my experiences from the development of a digital signal synthesis array driver and its use in our setup for ultra cold atom experiments.

SLOT2: Memes in the Cloud – Building a full-stack app with Golang and Google Cloud Platform in one week - Felix Raab

The talk will cover how to effectively build a production-ready, full-stack app with Golang and GCP in a short amount of time. I'll discuss how to approach making quick and sound technical decisions and how to apply modern software engineering practices for end-to-end apps. The presentation shows, in an opinionated and "meme-ful" way, various lessons learned, tools, and key takeaways for cloud environments.

SLOT3: go1.11 - dependency management and modules out of the box - Dmitry Savintsev

go1.11 recently introduced a brand new way of managing Go dependencies - go.mod file and related support built into the 'go' tool itself. The talk will describe the new mechanism and how to start using it, compare it with currently existing tools such as dep and glide, and share experiences of migrating codebases and CI builds to Go modules.

We are actively looking for speakers! Please approach me if you are interested to present either a talk of 40 min or just a lightning talk of 10-20 min

Cheers,
Sergii

events.name: June Meetup @Google
events.description:
Join us for the June edition of the Munich Gophers Meetup at Google.

Speakers:
---------------
• Talk 1: The Story of How and Why Uber is Using Go (Lena Morozova, Uber - Live from San Francisco, Thanks @Lena!)
• Talk 2: GoLand: Behind the Scenes (Artem Khvastunov, Jetbrains)

Agenda: TBD:
---------------

About The Speakers:

Lena Morozova from Uber will tell the story of how Go went from being used by a few enthusiastic developers at Uber to becoming the most popular language for microservices in use there. She'll talk about how they started and why they decided to use Go.

Some of the tips she'll address include:
• Dependency injection
• Consistent code structure
• Custom solutions: Fx and Glue
• Monorepo

Come learn where they failed and how that led them to solutions that they think are pretty darn neat.

Lena Morozova is a software engineer at the Go Platform Team at Uber where she works on Uber's Go ecosystem and wants to make Go experience more enjoyable at Uber. She is a co-organizer of the Women Who Go San Francisco meetup. She is excited about Go, hiking, and dancing.

Artem Khvastunov from Jetbrains will give us a behind-the-scenes look into GoLand. We live in a rapidly changing world. Every year Apple releases new macOS, Google ships Go once in six months, every five seconds Boeing 737 departs or lands, and once in a second a new JS framework appears or dies. It's a challenge to promptly adapt to all the changes and preserve quality at the same time. In this talk, I'll speak about processes and tools GoLand team uses to release a new version of the IDE every four months.

Some quick facts about Artem:
- Software developer at JetBrains
- Works on GoLand for more than a year
- Previously worked on PhpStorm
- Loves outdoor activities like hiking, biking, and snowboarding
- Lives in Munich, Germany

group_profile.intro: data guy with Python, R, Julia and Go
Excited about Go - a modern and versatile language that brings fun back to programming
